message: There are lots of devices that don't do DMA so just to be complete, people can still visualize it that way since if there is actually a byte by byte transfer and it's more common than you think, it will be interrupt driven and then handled by the DPC so again no (extra) O/S thread allocated for that. The device driver just has 4 (*) pieces of code: Load/Unload, I/O API, DPC and ISR - In the I/O request, the data is stored in RAM and then even without DMA, the DPC sends it out or receives it when queued by the ISR. (*) giant bunch of other stuff involving Power States does not apply to discussion.
